Dealing with multiple files

Source: vignettes/articles/multiple-files.Rmd
multiple-files.Rmd

Some googledrive functions are built to naturally handle multiple files, while others operate on a single file.

Functions that expect a single file:

  • drive_browse()
  • drive_cp()
  • drive_download()
  • drive_ls()
  • drive_mv()
  • drive_put()
  • drive_rename()
  • drive_update()
  • drive_upload()

Functions that allow multiple files:

  • drive_publish()
  • drive_reveal()
  • drive_rm()
  • drive_share()
  • drive_trash()

In general, the principle is: if there are multiple parameters that are likely to vary across multiple files, the function is designed to take a single input. In order to use these function with multiple inputs, use them together with your favorite approach for iteration in R. Below is a worked example, focusing on tools in the tidyverse, namely the map() functions in purrr.

Upload multiple files, then rename them

Scenario: we have multiple local files we want to upload into a folder on Drive. Then we regret their original names and want to rename them.

Load packages.

library(googledrive)
library(glue)
library(tidyverse)

Upload

Use the example files that ship with googledrive.

local_files <- drive_examples_local()
local_files <- set_names(local_files, basename(local_files))
local_files
#>                                                                         chicken.csv 
#>     "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/googledrive/extdata/example_files/chicken.csv" 
#>                                                                         chicken.jpg 
#>     "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/googledrive/extdata/example_files/chicken.jpg" 
#>                                                                         chicken.pdf 
#>     "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/googledrive/extdata/example_files/chicken.pdf" 
#>                                                                         chicken.txt 
#>     "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/googledrive/extdata/example_files/chicken.txt" 
#>                                                                     imdb_latin1.csv 
#> "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/googledrive/extdata/example_files/imdb_latin1.csv" 
#>                                                                        r_about.html 
#>    "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/googledrive/extdata/example_files/r_about.html" 
#>                                                                          r_logo.jpg 
#>      "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/googledrive/extdata/example_files/r_logo.jpg"

Create a folder on your Drive and upload all files into this folder by iterating over the local_files using purrr::map().

folder <- drive_mkdir("upload-into-me-article-demo")
#> Created Drive file:
#> â€¢ upload-into-me-article-demo <id: 17h1fEwHrW-DLUSdUEheYc5Kc0GOBN5lr>
#> With MIME type:
#> â€¢ application/vnd.google-apps.folder
with_drive_quiet(
  files <- map(local_files, ~ drive_upload(.x, path = folder))
)

First, letâ€™s confirm that we uploaded the files into the new folder.

drive_ls(folder)
#> # A dribble: 7 Ã— 3
#>   name            id                                drive_resource   
#>   <chr>           <drv_id>                          <list>           
#> 1 r_logo.jpg      1Y5aNHDBpePLzDYgtLSn_RpfFXJr9Da2y <named list [43]>
#> 2 r_about.html    1HDdz9aaXlDDLNCzaKnhnaim_Wwne0WHZ <named list [42]>
#> 3 imdb_latin1.csv 1x0kziyvNpPa61KqB918eF-dqeYnPLePE <named list [41]>
#> 4 chicken.txt     1VKTbEUniXRVjh00Tg2aXTvrHxFcwsgHw <named list [42]>
#> 5 chicken.pdf     1WqLMZb8zNv_BIfuqWDQu5K4LkcxZ0Ocy <named list [42]>
#> 6 chicken.jpg     13d-U0LAxjRlYZNWAyGzYerJcHhIU41O9 <named list [43]>
#> 7 chicken.csv     1wF9SfFdf_IrHDrDODZHz_solVDqQDSSl <named list [41]>

Now letâ€™s reflect on the files object returned by this operation. files is a list of dribbles, one per uploaded file.

str(files, max.level = 1)
#> List of 7
#>  $ chicken.csv    : dribble [1 Ã— 3] (S3: dribble/tbl_df/tbl/data.frame)
#>  $ chicken.jpg    : dribble [1 Ã— 3] (S3: dribble/tbl_df/tbl/data.frame)
#>  $ chicken.pdf    : dribble [1 Ã— 3] (S3: dribble/tbl_df/tbl/data.frame)
#>  $ chicken.txt    : dribble [1 Ã— 3] (S3: dribble/tbl_df/tbl/data.frame)
#>  $ imdb_latin1.csv: dribble [1 Ã— 3] (S3: dribble/tbl_df/tbl/data.frame)
#>  $ r_about.html   : dribble [1 Ã— 3] (S3: dribble/tbl_df/tbl/data.frame)
#>  $ r_logo.jpg     : dribble [1 Ã— 3] (S3: dribble/tbl_df/tbl/data.frame)

This would be a favorable data structure if youâ€™ve got more map()ing to do, as youâ€™ll see below.

But what if not? You can always row bind individual dribbles into one big dribble yourself with, e.g., dplyr::bind_rows().

bind_rows(files)
#> # A dribble: 7 Ã— 3
#>   name            id                                drive_resource   
#>   <chr>           <drv_id>                          <list>           
#> 1 chicken.csv     1wF9SfFdf_IrHDrDODZHz_solVDqQDSSl <named list [41]>
#> 2 chicken.jpg     13d-U0LAxjRlYZNWAyGzYerJcHhIU41O9 <named list [43]>
#> 3 chicken.pdf     1WqLMZb8zNv_BIfuqWDQu5K4LkcxZ0Ocy <named list [41]>
#> 4 chicken.txt     1VKTbEUniXRVjh00Tg2aXTvrHxFcwsgHw <named list [41]>
#> 5 imdb_latin1.csv 1x0kziyvNpPa61KqB918eF-dqeYnPLePE <named list [41]>
#> 6 r_about.html    1HDdz9aaXlDDLNCzaKnhnaim_Wwne0WHZ <named list [41]>
#> 7 r_logo.jpg      1Y5aNHDBpePLzDYgtLSn_RpfFXJr9Da2y <named list [43]>

Below we show another way to finesse this by using a variant of purrr::map() that does this for us, namely map_dfr().

Rename

Imagine that we now wish these file names had a date prefix. First, form the new names. We use glue::glue() for string interpolation but you could also use paste(). Second, we map over two inputs: the list of dribbles from above and the vector of new names.

(new_names <- glue("{Sys.Date()}_{basename(local_files)}"))
#> 2024-08-06_chicken.csv
#> 2024-08-06_chicken.jpg
#> 2024-08-06_chicken.pdf
#> 2024-08-06_chicken.txt
#> 2024-08-06_imdb_latin1.csv
#> 2024-08-06_r_about.html
#> 2024-08-06_r_logo.jpg
files_dribble <- map2_dfr(files, new_names, drive_rename)
#> Original file:
#> â€¢ chicken.csv <id: 1wF9SfFdf_IrHDrDODZHz_solVDqQDSSl>
#> Has been renamed:
#> â€¢ 2024-08-06_chicken.csv <id: 1wF9SfFdf_IrHDrDODZHz_solVDqQDSSl>
#> Original file:
#> â€¢ chicken.jpg <id: 13d-U0LAxjRlYZNWAyGzYerJcHhIU41O9>
#> Has been renamed:
#> â€¢ 2024-08-06_chicken.jpg <id: 13d-U0LAxjRlYZNWAyGzYerJcHhIU41O9>
#> Original file:
#> â€¢ chicken.pdf <id: 1WqLMZb8zNv_BIfuqWDQu5K4LkcxZ0Ocy>
#> Has been renamed:
#> â€¢ 2024-08-06_chicken.pdf <id: 1WqLMZb8zNv_BIfuqWDQu5K4LkcxZ0Ocy>
#> Original file:
#> â€¢ chicken.txt <id: 1VKTbEUniXRVjh00Tg2aXTvrHxFcwsgHw>
#> Has been renamed:
#> â€¢ 2024-08-06_chicken.txt <id: 1VKTbEUniXRVjh00Tg2aXTvrHxFcwsgHw>
#> Original file:
#> â€¢ imdb_latin1.csv <id: 1x0kziyvNpPa61KqB918eF-dqeYnPLePE>
#> Has been renamed:
#> â€¢ 2024-08-06_imdb_latin1.csv <id: 1x0kziyvNpPa61KqB918eF-dqeYnPLePE>
#> Original file:
#> â€¢ r_about.html <id: 1HDdz9aaXlDDLNCzaKnhnaim_Wwne0WHZ>
#> Has been renamed:
#> â€¢ 2024-08-06_r_about.html <id: 1HDdz9aaXlDDLNCzaKnhnaim_Wwne0WHZ>
#> Original file:
#> â€¢ r_logo.jpg <id: 1Y5aNHDBpePLzDYgtLSn_RpfFXJr9Da2y>
#> Has been renamed:
#> â€¢ 2024-08-06_r_logo.jpg <id: 1Y5aNHDBpePLzDYgtLSn_RpfFXJr9Da2y>

We use purrr::map2_dfr() to work through files, the list of dribbles (= Drive files), and new_names, the vector of new names, and row bind the returned dribbles into a single dribble holding all files.

Letâ€™s check on the contents of this folder again to confirm the new names:

drive_ls(folder)
#> # A dribble: 7 Ã— 3
#>   name                       id       drive_resource   
#>   <chr>                      <drv_id> <list>           
#> 1 2024-08-06_r_logo.jpg      1Y5aNHDâ€¦ <named list [43]>
#> 2 2024-08-06_r_about.html    1HDdz9aâ€¦ <named list [42]>
#> 3 2024-08-06_imdb_latin1.csv 1x0kziyâ€¦ <named list [41]>
#> 4 2024-08-06_chicken.txt     1VKTbEUâ€¦ <named list [42]>
#> 5 2024-08-06_chicken.pdf     1WqLMZbâ€¦ <named list [42]>
#> 6 2024-08-06_chicken.jpg     13d-U0Lâ€¦ <named list [43]>
#> 7 2024-08-06_chicken.csv     1wF9SfFâ€¦ <named list [41]>

Letâ€™s confirm that, by using map2_df2() instead of map2(), we got a single dribble back, instead of a list of one-row dribbles:

files_dribble
#> # A dribble: 7 Ã— 3
#>   name                       id       drive_resource   
#>   <chr>                      <drv_id> <list>           
#> 1 2024-08-06_chicken.csv     1wF9SfFâ€¦ <named list [41]>
#> 2 2024-08-06_chicken.jpg     13d-U0Lâ€¦ <named list [43]>
#> 3 2024-08-06_chicken.pdf     1WqLMZbâ€¦ <named list [42]>
#> 4 2024-08-06_chicken.txt     1VKTbEUâ€¦ <named list [42]>
#> 5 2024-08-06_imdb_latin1.csv 1x0kziyâ€¦ <named list [41]>
#> 6 2024-08-06_r_about.html    1HDdz9aâ€¦ <named list [42]>
#> 7 2024-08-06_r_logo.jpg      1Y5aNHDâ€¦ <named list [43]>

What if you wanted to get a list back, because your downstream operations include yet more map()ing? Then you would use map2().

files_list <- map2(files, new_names, drive_rename)

Clean up

Our trashing function, drive_trash() is vectorized and can therefore operate on a multi-file dribble. We could trash these files like so:

drive_trash(files_dribble)

If youâ€™re absolutely sure of yourself and happy to do something irreversible, you could truly delete these files with drive_rm(), which is also vectorized:

drive_rm(files_dribble)

Finally â€“ and this is the code we will actually execute â€“ the easiest way to delete these files is to delete their enclosing folder.

drive_rm(folder)
#> File deleted:
#> â€¢ upload-into-me-article-demo <id: 17h1fEwHrW-DLUSdUEheYc5Kc0GOBN5lr>
